beats.text: This is a demonstration of the GUI Chat Protocol in action.
The user just typed “hi” to start the conversation.
The LLM, acting as a recipe guide, dynamically generates a form and calls the presentForm tool to display it.
Notice that the form is presented to the user as part of the chat application interface.
This style of interaction is enabled by the GUI Chat Protocol, and it is easier than asking the user to type everything in free-form text.
When the user fills out the form and submits it, the chat application forwards the submission to the LLM.
From the LLM’s perspective, this looks just like a normal message from the user, formatted as a JSON object.
The schema of this JSON object is defined by the LLM itself when it calls the presentForm tool.
The presentForm tool is a powerful feature because it allows the LLM to receive structured data from the user, which is difficult with traditional text-based chat applications.
Based on this structured response, the LLM generates a recipe document in an enhanced version of Markdown and calls the presentDocument tool.
This enhanced Markdown format allows the LLM to embed images in the document by specifying an image prompt for each one.
The presentDocument tool then generates those images from the prompts and embeds them into the document.
Notice that the generated document with embedded images is much more engaging than a plain text response from a typical chat application.
At its core, the GUI Chat Protocol extends existing tool calling by adding one simple idea: typed GUI output.
The LLM continues to see only tools and text responses. It does not need to understand anything about the user interface.
When a tool returns structured data with a specific type, the chat application renders the appropriate visual component automatically.
This keeps the protocol model-agnostic and compatible with any LLM that supports function or tool calling.
GUI Chat Protocol is an open protocol, designed to be simple, extensible, and easy to adopt.
A reference implementation is available as open source, demonstrating how these ideas can be built on top of existing chat infrastructure.
Looking ahead, this approach enables a future where chat becomes the primary user interface, and tools replace traditional applications.
Instead of launching apps and learning interfaces, users simply express intent, and the system assembles the right tools and visuals on demand.
GUI Chat Protocol provides a foundation for that future: conversational, visual, interactive, and open by design.
